BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 23, 1911.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MR. GLENN NOW A TRUSTEE

DR. GILDERSLEEVE IS EIGHTY

LACROSSE SCHEDULE COMPLETE

M. A. C. NOT EASY PREY

Becomes a Member of the Board in
Place of Mr. Waldo
Newcomer.

And Is Celebrating His Birthday Today.

Vigorous in mind and body after
fifty-five years' service as one of
the world's foremost professors of
Greek, Dr. Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve, who has been a member of
the faculty of the Johns Hopkins
University since its foundation in
1876, celebrates today his eightieth
birthday.
In spite of his four score years,
Dr. Gildersleeve is "young," and his
sparkling wit, which makes alive
the most technical of his writings upon the .subjects which have
brought him fame at home and
abroad, is as keen and spontaneous
as when he first chose Baltimore as
his place of abode.
The passing of the eightieth milestone wil be marked by no ceremonies, and Profesor Gildersleeve
will spend the clay quietly at his
home with his family. On the part
of his students, no demonstration
is planned, but at the meeting of
the Philological Society on Friday,
the "Grand Old Man" of the Hopkins faculty was warmly congratulated.
Dr. Gildersleeve's life, unlike that
of many educators, has. not been
one-sided. His activities have not
been confined to the one subject
which he teaches. He is recognized
as a world famous Latin scholar,
and the grammar which he has prepared is considered as the authority.
His published writings have been
on many subjects and are known
for their wit and spontaneity as
well as their euridition. Last year
a charming lecture on Rostand's
"Chantecleer" was delivered by Dr.,
Gildersleeve.
"Do you know," he remarked the
other day, "that I came very near
being a newspaper man instead of
a professor? As a matter of fact,
I have done considerable work for
newspapers and magazines. I have

ohn Glenn, Jr., of Baltimore, has been elected a member
of the Board of Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins University to fill
the vacancy made by the resignation of Mr. Waldo Newcomer. Mr.
Glenn is a Hopkins alumnus and
has always been actively interested
in his alma mater. He was graduated in 1885 with the degree of
bachelor of arts, and two years
later he completed the law course
at the University of Maryland. He
has been one of Baltimore's leading real estate brokers for a number of years. Mr. Glenn contributed liberally to the Homewood
Endowment and Extension Fund.
He is a cousin of Mr. John M.
Glenn, the sociologist and philanthropist, formerly of Baltimore, but
now living in New York, where he
filling the position of secretary
and director of the Russel Sage
to,opo,000 Foundation for the uplift of the poor.
The reason why Mr. Newcomer
resigned has not been announced.
Ile had nothing to say when he was
asked why he had resigned. Mr.
Newcomer had been a member of
the Board of Trustees for about
six years. He also is a Hopkins
alumnus.
Mr. B. Howell Griswold was
elected a member of the Board of
Trustees early this year to fill the
place of the late Richard M. Venable.
The Board of Trustees now numbers its full quota. The Trustees
are: R. Brent Keyser, president;
Eugene Levering, Bernard N. Baker, Francis M. Jencks, Theodore
.larburp-, Blanchard Randall, Henry
H
arlIn, Miles White, Jr.; William H. Buckler, Thomas J. Morris, B. Howell Griswold, Jr., and
John Glenn, Jr.

TWO important announcements in
connection with Hopkins athletics
were made last week. One was that
an excellent lacrosse schedule had
been arranged, and the other was
that Princeton would come to Baltimore on April 4, for a baseball
game with the 'Varsity team.
In addition to the regular games
of the lacrosse league, Manager
Burg-an has arranged contests with
Carlisle Indians, Harvard, Cornell,
and Navy. The place for the game
with the Indians has not been determined upon, but will probably
be at Homewood. The Navy game
will be at Annapolis.
The only unfortunate feature of
the schedule is the date for the
Navy game. This has proved for
the last two years to be one of
the hardest of the season and should
be arranged to come later. There
is no game sCheduled with Mount
Washington, but it may turn out
that one can be arranged for May
18, the regular season closing with
Lehigh at South Bethlehem on May
II.
The schedule follows:
March 24—Alumni at Homewood.
March 31—Navy at Annapolis.
April 6—Cornell at Homewood.
April 13—Harvard at Homewood.
April 20—Carlisle (undecided).
April 27—Stevens at Hoboken.
May 4—Swarthmore at Homewood.
May 11—Lehigh at South Bethlehem.
The announcement of the game
with Princeton is a forerunner of
even more pleasing news which the
baseball management promises. Baltimore is a big Princeton town and
after the great showing which the
team made last year against Harvard and Pennsylvania a big crowd
should be present.
Because the football games on
Saturday were largely swimming
matches, it is difficult to dope out
any comparisons from the scores.
St. John's, however, put up a game
fight against Virginia. Swarthmore
put it all cwer Stevens, whose team
was licked by Hopkins with a bare
two points margin. Swarthmore
on the 14th beat Virginia by one
point. \
Here are the scores:
Virginia, 6: St. John's, o.
Carlisle Indians, 17; Pittsburgh,
a
Swarthmore, 16; Stevens, 0.

Hopkins defeated Maryland Agricultural College, Saturday afternoon
at Homewood, but the visitors put
up a game fight, and at times had
a shade the better of the contest.
The score, 6 to 3, was due to a
touchdown by Bishop, goal from
touchdown by Fulton, and a dropkick by Shipley. •
The game was played on a muddy field. Fumbles were frequent,
and the game was anything but
fast. The Black and Blue team
seemed to lack the ginger that has
marked its playing in the last two
games, and their line, although
fairly heavy, was unable to break
through the Aggies' wall for substantial gains. •
.
In the first quarter the visitors
had the better of the fight. The
field was wet, and this seemed to
help them materially. Fulton kicked
to their io-yard line, and they went
down the field, making first down
in a few seconds. Hopkins forced
them to punt, however, but when
the 'Varsity tried to advance end
runs were used almost exclusively,
and Johnson and Kemp, the two
opposing ends, prevented the Hopkins backs.from advancing.
On the defensive, also, in this -quarter the Hopkins play was ragged, and a fumble and a poor attempt at a forward pass gave the
collegians the ball on the 25-yard
line. .From here Shipley tried to
kick a field goal, but it was blocked
by Hopkins, and Gillet punted to
safety. Two minutes later Shipley
tried a drop kick from the same
distance as before, although at a
more difficult angle, and this tune
it went over.
In the second quarter Hopkins
took a decided brace and forced the
fighting. During this session the
ball was in the Aggies' territory
much of the time. It was on their
25-yard line when they started to
Work a kick formation by which
the fullback is sent through the
line. Vinder dropped. back, but
somehow the pass from Koehler
rolled on the ground. Bishop got
through the line, seized the pigskin,
shook off one opposing player who
grabbed him and started for the
line. Belt helped him on and the
touchdown was scored. Fulton
kicked 'goal.
In the third period "By." Bridgman, the hero of many games at
Homewood, went in and did some
star Nvork. Several times he tore

FIELD NIGHT AT HOPKINS CLUB
Dr. Mustard Delivers an Illustrated Lecture on "Roman Buildings in
Southern France."

The first monthly field night of
the johns Hopkins Club was held
on Saturday evening. Mr. George
Cator, the president of the Club,
was in the chair, and Prof. Wilfred
P. Mustard gave an illustrated lecture on "Roman Buildings in Southern France." Professor Mustard
said, in part:
"I am to speak this evening
of one small region in Southern
France, and show you a series of
photographs which I have collected
within the last three or four years.
They illustrate a group of ancient
Roman buildings which are not
often visited by travellers from this
part of the world, although in point
of age and workmanship and state
of preservation, they rank with anything of the sort to be seen in Italy,
or elsewhere in Europe. Indeed,
some of them far surpass anything
of their particular kind, even in
Rome itself.
shall not try to cover this
whole region in a single hour, but
speak mainly of three important
places, namely, Arles, and Nimes,
and Orange. And yet, taking only
these three • places, I can show you
a group of Roman monuments
which are apt to surprise anyone
who has not seen them. At Arles
and at Nimes we have two great
stone amphitheatres, one of them
in a quite surprising state of preservation. At Nimes we have also the
Maison Carree, one of the finest
and best preserved Roman temples
in the world. Then there is the
famous aqueduct known as the Pont
du Gard, which is perhaps the finest
portion of a Roman aqueduct ever
built. And at Orange we shall see
one of the oldest triumphal arches
still standing, as well as a great
,Roman theatre, which is simply
unique in Europe. This group of
buildings is very important to any
student of ancient history or of
ancient architecture; and they are
the more impressive because they
are all comprised in one little district about forty miles square."
The lecture was illustrated with
excellent lantern slides throughout.
Some of the most impressive and
best preserved of the buildings
shown were the two amphitheatres
at Arles and at Nimes, the Maison
Carree, the arch and the theatre at
Orange, and the Pont du Gard.
The amphitheatre at Nimes is 144
yards long and 109 yards wide, and
the exterior is much better preserved than that of any other
amphitheatre in Italy or France.
The Maison Carree is not only the
most beautiful, but also one of the
oldest Roman temples still standing.
The great arch at Orange is probably one of the oldest triumphal
arches known, as it certainly is one
of the most richly and profusely
decorated, and withal, one of the
best preserved. Time has softened

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 23, 1911.
it to a mellow golden tint; and
under the bright blue sky of Provence it is one of the most impressive memorials of the Roman occupation. The theatre is unique
among the ancient theatres of Europe, in that the stage-wall has been
very well preserved. The facade
is 335 feet long, and 120 feet high.
The stage itself was 203 feet wide,
and 42 feet deep.
The Pont du Gard is part of a
great aqueduct which once carried
water across the valley of the Gardon to the city of Nimes. It is
88o feet long, and tho feet high.
It is composed of three rows of
arches: The lowest tier of 6, the
second of ii, and the third of 35.
This magnificent structure was
thoroughly illustrated from half a
dozen different points of view. Here
the lecturer took occasion to correct a rather common impression,
namely, that the ancient aqueducts
were constructed throughout their
entire course upon arches. As a
matter of fact, only a relatively
small proportion of any aqueduct
was so built. The larger part was
regularly underground. This is
true even of the numerous aqueducts which brought such a bountiful supply of pure water to the city
of Rome itself. One thinks, of
course, of the great arches, some
of them even 90 feet high, which
go striding across the Campagna in
such impressive fashion; but we
know from the treatise of Froptinus, who was water commissioner
of the city about '00 A. D., that in
every case the greater part of the
aqueduct ran underground.

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 23, 1911.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(THE NEws-LETUR is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed Vvith the name of the writer,
which, upon request,. will be withheld.)

October 19, 1911.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LErrER :

Dear Sir—For more than thirtyfive years our University has been
established on Maryland soil. It is
amply old enough to have associated
itself with the traditions of the
State. It has had ample time to
win its way into the affections of
the people. And yet the. paltry allowance which it expects from the
public coffers is granted more and
more grudgingly by every succeeding, Legislature. The vast, majority
of the people of Maryland—nay,
even a majority of the inhabitants
of Baltimore—seem never to have
heard of the Johns Hopkins University ; or if they have heard of it,
they think of it as an institution
which for some unknown reason or
other is always clamoring for public charity.. What is the reason for
such a condition of affairs?
.
Perhaps the • people of Maryland
do not "go in for" higher education ; perhaps many of them are
bound by ties of tradition to some
institution outside the State. But
be this as it may, in one particular
the University is itself responsible.
It has subordinated undergraduate
to graduate instruction. It has not
catered to undergraduate students.
It has, therefore, not adequately
supplied that form of instruction
which Maryland primarily needs;
and it has not made use of its opportunities to put itself in closer
touch with the people of the State.

Graduate students seldom come
into touch in after years with the
great body of the people; they seldom develop into leaders of public
opinion. They go forth from their
alma mater to occupy chairs in other
universities, and to spend their days
accumulating and dispensing knowledge. They live and die amid the
circle of the learned, unheard of
by the common run of mankind.
Such men seldom possess any opportunity of making widely known
or generally loved the name of the
institution which has sent them
forth. Nor can they aid that institution materially themselves, being
for the most part poor in the goods
of this world. Such men constitute
the larger part of the alumni of
Hopkins. From them it can expect
little assistance of any kind, either
toward meeting current expenses,
or toward "getting out to Homewood."
Of course it may be said that it
is far nobler on the part of an institution to pursue single mindedly
the advancement of learning than to
seek to butter its bread by catering
to a larger body of collegiate students ; and the argument seems
plausible enough. But to the State
it is certainly of far greater importance that its lawyers, its physicians,' its divines, and its leaders of
public opinion in general, be men
of broad intelligence and culture
than that some new chemical property or historical document be discovered. It is immeasurably better
for a State to contain within its
borders a thousand college graduates and one doctor of philosophy
than a hundred doctors of philosophy and a hundred college graduates. The State must provide for
undergraduate instruction primarily,
for graduate instruction only secondarily; and if the Johns Hopkins
deliberately chooses then to cater
primarily to graduate students, it
must expect to see its claims upon
State aid subordinated to the claims
of Washington College, St. John's
and Western Maryland.
\s a friend of the University, I
have wished to offer these objections
to what seems to me a mistaken
policy. The question of policy,
however, is of course purely within
the discretion of the University; and
no one • has a right to say that it
ought to do this or it ought to do
that. But it is within the right of
everyone to say that it ought not
to dissemble its policy; and it is
in this particular that, as a member
of the University, and an undergraduate student, I wish to find
most grievous fault with its attitude.
It is marching under false colors.
Hardly a commencement goes by at
which one member of the faculty or
another does not proclaim to the

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 23, 1911
Undergraduate Privileges.

THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to call
the attention of the library authorities to a letter in the correspondence
column concerning the partial exclusion of undergraduates from the
branch libraries on the second floor.
If the allegations contained in the
letter are true, they are serious
enough to call for immediate remedy.
Students, as we understand it, are
permitted to borrow books from the
-Historical Library, but the use of
its rooms for reading or for examination of the books on the
shelves is distinctly discouraged.
Under the system which we have at
Hopkins, the most important works
on the different subjects must be
placed in the seminary rooms, and
with the exception of the works on
English literature, the books in the
main reading-room are the cast-offs
of the various departmental libraries.
That undergraduates should not
be permitted and even encouraged
to use the books, with the same assistance from attendants as is accorded those who go into the main
reading-room, is almost inconceivable. Some of the books on the
third floor are locked in cases, and
the undergraduate who asks that
these be opened is thought to be exceding his rights. The letter which
we print today may be slightly
exaggerated, but it voices a just
Protest. Graduates and undergraduates should be permitted to share
alike in the library facilities which
the University offers.
College Women and Divorce.

Recent statistics of the use of the
divorce court by women college
graduates to settle their matrimonial
difficulties, reveal the surprising fact
that only one out of every fiftyseven unions entered into by them
ends in this way. The complete

divorce statistics. for the United
of, every
States show that one out of
twelve marriages is such a
that its final act is played in a law
court.
Comparing these two sets of figures, we come to the obvious conclusion that during their stay in
college, women have learned, in addition to their studies, some things
which fit them for married life,
and so it can be maintained that if
all women were sent to college, the
proportion of divorces to marriages
would be materially lessened. The
careful scrutinizer of these statistics, could, moreover, argue that
if he married a college girl, he
would stand 475 per cent. more
chance of finding bliss in the union.
No statistics are given for college
widows.
This method of reasoning is,
however, incomplete, for the figures
do not distinguish between types.
There is one set of people among
whom divorces are more common
than one in every twelve; there are
some sets, the poorer element, for
instance, where there is not one divorce in a hundred marriages. That
scientist who will discover what is
the average ratio for the great mass
of the population will be doing a
great service, but meantime it is
safe to say that it is not greater
than one in thirty.
The matrimonial question has two
aspects in the light of these figures.
If you marry a college girl, the
chances in favor of a divorce are
one to fifty-seven; if your choice
does not fall on a sweet girl graduate, some consideration should be
given to the question whether the
object of your affections belongs
to the larger and happier body of
the community, or to that small section of it which breeds the greatest
number of divorces. College women,
therefore. ought to stand a better
opportunity of getting married.

The Old Brown Hat.
I wonder where the Old Brown Hat
We knew and loved so long, is at—
The Old Brown Hat that Latin One
Observed with each day's rising still,
And watched with far intenser rage
Than e'er they gave .to Livy's page?
So now its sacred place cloth hold
An Alpine gray of rakish mould.
Where can that Old Brown Hat now be
Shall we no more its contour see?
Without its ancient form; Room •Six
Is as unnatural as the Styx
Bereft of Charon, or as is the
Name of Pyramus without Thisbe!
Weep, freshmen, for that Old Brown
Hat—
We don't know where it now is at!

The cheering section at the game
with Al aryland Agricultural College
on Saturday was not as large as it
should be, and at times the efforts
at organized yells were puny. There
were some few fellows who gathered around Mr. Price, the cheerleader for this season, but many
remained in other parts of the stand
with the lady friends whom they
had escorted to see the game.
Announcement has been made
that practices for the especial benefit of the freshmen will be held this
week, and all students, new and old,
are urged to attend. The songs and
yells will be rehearsed, so that at
the game with Gettysburg, on Saturday, a better showing can be
made.
After the game on last Saturday,
Manager Getz, of the football team,
made the following statement:
"The coaehes, Captain Fulton and
myself want to appeal to all undergraduates, graduates and alumni
who attend the games, and ask
them to sit in the portion of the
stand which is reserved for the
cheering section. If the team is expected to play good football this
year, the students will have to show
that they are backing the team, for
eleven men, no matter how well.
trained they may be, cannot play
their best game unless they know
that they are getting support on the
side lines.
"The students should attend the
.games and cheer, not only when
the team is playing well and winning, but when mistakes are made.
When a man fumbles the ball, or
fails to gain, he gets disheartened
and on the next play loses some of
his vim ; but when he hears the
'Varsity yell with his name tacked
on the end, and knows that the
students are with him, he is encouraged, and plays all the harder.
At the game Saturday,the Maryland
Agricultural College rooters often
out-velled us, and undergraduates of
an institution of the prestige of
Johns Hopkins shouldn't for a moment allow this. With a team like
the one we have, and representing
a great University, we should outyell the rooters of any team which
plays at Homewood.'

In an authoritative statement concerning the rank of different American colleges in athletics, which was
recently published, Johns Hopkins
was placed fourth. Cornell was
given first 'place with five points;
Yale second, with four and a half;
Princeton third, with two and a
half, and Hopkins, Harvard, Pennsylvania, Columbia, Haverford, and
Annapolis were listed as tied for
fourth place with one point each.
One point was given to each college for each of the intercollegiate
championships held by it in one of
the sixteen sports considered. Cornell won its place by holding the
championship in rowing, crosscountry, track, hockey and fencing. To Yale is conceded first place
in golf, shooting, water polo and
swimming, gymnastics, and 'a tie in
tennis. Princeton has a tie in tennis and first place in baseball and
wrestling. Last Year Harvard had
the best team in football, Haverford in association football, Columbia in basketball, and Hopkins in
lacrosse. The fact that Hopkins
was given as high a standing as
Harvard and Columbia shows how
highly outsiders regard our athletic
ability.

Social Service Meeting.

The first of the series of meetings
held during the year by the Association will be held on Tuesday,
October 24, at 5 P. M. The suSject of the meeting will be the "Social Service Needs of Baltimore."
Talks will be given by Dr. Magruder, secretary of the Federated
Charities, and Mr. hackney, of the
Central Y. M. C. A., who has
charge of the work of teaching;
English to foreigners. The opportunities for service in the city are
numerous and varied and we hope
that many students vill attend the
meeting, although it may be impossible for them to take up any
phase of the work.

Bible Classes Organize.

The Bible Study Classes arc now
in full swing. The freshman class
studying the Life of Jesus meets in
two groups, Monday at nine o'clock,
and Friday at ten o'clock. If there
are any freshmen who intend to
enroll in these classes, but who have
not done so as yet, we wish they
would see the general secretary at
once. The sophomor class studying
the Acts and the Epistles will meet
on Friday at one o'clock. The
junior class, studying the Teachings
of the Phophets meets on Monday
at one o'clock. The senior class,
studying the Social Teachings of
Jesus, • meets on Friday at one
o'clock.
If sufficient number of men are
secured a class will be organized
for the men who have doubts and
difficulties regarding religious matters. Any students.-- desiring to
enter this class will please speak
to the general secretary about the
matter.
A cordial invitation is extended
to all students to enroll in one of
these groups.

He began writing while still in
his native State—South - Carolina.
His father, the late Benjamin Gildersleeve, of Charleston, was editor
of a religious paper, and Dr. Gildersleeve, then a young man, frequently contributed to that periodical. While at the -University of
Virginia he wrote for a newspaper
in Richmond.
"I even wrote a novel once," he
remarked reminiscently. "I was
then 23 years old. It was never
published, and the manuscript I still
have. I have written some poetry
too. In 1890 I collected my contributions to periodicals and published them in book form under
the title of 'Essays and Studies.'
Some of my verse is contained in
this."
From literature Dr. Gildersleeve
turned to _the topic of the Civil War.
The students and the faculty of the
University of Virginia were exempt
from service in the army, but the
Professor said he usually "spent
his vacations at the front." His
career as a Confederate soldier was
varied. Private, lieutenant and captain, he was in many engagements.

Vigorous in mind and body after
fifty-five years' service as one of
the world's foremost professors of
Greek, Dr. Basil Lanneau Gildersleeve, who has been a member of
the faculty of the Johns Hopkins
University since its foundation in
1876, celebrates today his eightieth
birthday.
In spite of his four score years,
Dr. Gildersleeve is "young," and his
sparkling wit, which makes alive
the most technical of his writings upon the .subjects which have
brought him fame at home and
abroad, is as keen and spontaneous
as when he first chose Baltimore as
his place of abode.
The passing of the eightieth milestone wil be marked by no ceremonies, and Profesor Gildersleeve
will spend the clay quietly at his
home with his family. On the part
of his students, no demonstration
is planned, but at the meeting of
the Philological Society on Friday,
the "Grand Old Man" of the Hopkins faculty was warmly congratulated.
Dr. Gildersleeve's life, unlike that
of many educators, has. not been
one-sided. His activities have not
been confined to the one subject
which he teaches. He is recognized
as a world famous Latin scholar,
and the grammar which he has prepared is considered as the authority.
His published writings have been
on many subjects and are known
for their wit and spontaneity as
well as their euridition. Last year
a charming lecture on Rostand's
"Chantecleer" was delivered by Dr.,
Gildersleeve.

ohn Glenn, Jr., of Baltimore, has been elected a member
of the Board of Trustees of the
Johns Hopkins University to fill
the vacancy made by the resignation of Mr. Waldo Newcomer. Mr.
Glenn is a Hopkins alumnus and
has always been actively interested
in his alma mater. He was graduated in 1885 with the degree of
bachelor of arts, and two years
later he completed the law course
at the University of Maryland. He
has been one of Baltimore's leading real estate brokers for a number of years. Mr. Glenn contributed liberally to the Homewood
Endowment and Extension Fund.
He is a cousin of Mr. John M.
Glenn, the sociologist and philanthropist, formerly of Baltimore, but
now living in New York, where he
filling the position of secretary
and director of the Russel Sage
to,opo,000 Foundation for the uplift of the poor.
The reason why Mr. Newcomer
resigned has not been announced.
Ile had nothing to say when he was
asked why he had resigned. Mr.
Newcomer had been a member of
the Board of Trustees for about
six years. He also is a Hopkins
alumnus.
Mr. B. Howell Griswold was
elected a member of the Board of
Trustees early this year to fill the
place of the late Richard M. Venable.
The Board of Trustees now numbers its full quota. The Trustees
are: R. Brent Keyser, president;

TWO important announcements in
connection with Hopkins athletics
were made last week. One was that
an excellent lacrosse schedule had
been arranged, and the other was
that Princeton would come to Baltimore on April 4, for a baseball
game with the 'Varsity team.
In addition to the regular games
of the lacrosse league, Manager
Burg-an has arranged contests with
Carlisle Indians, Harvard, Cornell,
and Navy. The place for the game
with the Indians has not been determined upon, but will probably
be at Homewood. The Navy game
will be at Annapolis.
The only unfortunate feature of
the schedule is the date for the
Navy game. This has proved for
the last two years to be one of
the hardest of the season and should
be arranged to come later. There
is no game sCheduled with Mount
Washington, but it may turn out
that one can be arranged for May
18, the regular season closing with
Lehigh at South Bethlehem on May
II.
The schedule follows:
March 24—Alumni at Homewood.
March 31—Navy at Annapolis.
April 6—Cornell at Homewood.
April 13—Harvard at Homewood.
April 20—Carlisle (undecided).
April 27—Stevens at Hoboken.
May 4—Swarthmore at Homewood.
May 11—Lehigh at South Bethlehem.
The announcement of the game
with Princeton is a forerunner of
even more pleasing news which the
baseball management promises. Baltimore is a big Princeton town and
after the great showing which the
team made last year against Harvard and Pennsylvania a big crowd
should be present.

FIELD NIGHT AT HOPKINS CLUB
Dr. Mustard Delivers an Illustrated Lecture on "Roman Buildings in
Southern France."

The first monthly field night of
the johns Hopkins Club was held
on Saturday evening. Mr. George
Cator, the president of the Club,
was in the chair, and Prof. Wilfred
P. Mustard gave an illustrated lecture on "Roman Buildings in Southern France." Professor Mustard
said, in part:
"I am to speak this evening
of one small region in Southern
France, and show you a series of
photographs which I have collected
within the last three or four years.
They illustrate a group of ancient
Roman buildings which are not
often visited by travellers from this
part of the world, although in point
of age and workmanship and state
of preservation, they rank with anything of the sort to be seen in Italy,
or elsewhere in Europe. Indeed,
some of them far surpass anything
of their particular kind, even in
Rome itself.
shall not try to cover this
whole region in a single hour, but
speak mainly of three important
places, namely, Arles, and Nimes,
and Orange. And yet, taking only
these three • places, I can show you
a group of Roman monuments
which are apt to surprise anyone
who has not seen them. At Arles
and at Nimes we have two great
stone amphitheatres, one of them
in a quite surprising state of preservation. At Nimes we have also the
Maison Carree, one of the finest
and best preserved Roman temples
in the world. Then there is the
famous aqueduct known as the Pont
du Gard, which is perhaps the finest
portion of a Roman aqueduct ever
built. And at Orange we shall see
one of the oldest triumphal arches
still standing, as well as a great
,Roman theatre, which is simply
unique in Europe. This group of
buildings is very important to any
student of ancient history or of
ancient architecture; and they are
the more impressive because they
are all comprised in one little district about forty miles square."
The lecture was illustrated with
excellent lantern slides throughout.
Some of the most impressive and
best preserved of the buildings
shown were the two amphitheatres
at Arles and at Nimes, the Maison
Carree, the arch and the theatre at
Orange, and the Pont du Gard.
The amphitheatre at Nimes is 144
yards long and 109 yards wide, and
the exterior is much better preserved than that of any other
amphitheatre in Italy or France.
The Maison Carree is not only the
most beautiful, but also one of the
oldest Roman temples still standing.
The great arch at Orange is probably one of the oldest triumphal
arches known, as it certainly is one
of the most richly and profusely
decorated, and withal, one of the
best preserved. Time has softened

THE NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 23, 1911.
it to a mellow golden tint; and
under the bright blue sky of Provence it is one of the most impressive memorials of the Roman occupation. The theatre is unique
among the ancient theatres of Europe, in that the stage-wall has been
very well preserved. The facade
is 335 feet long, and 120 feet high.
The stage itself was 203 feet wide,
and 42 feet deep.
The Pont du Gard is part of a
great aqueduct which once carried
water across the valley of the Gardon to the city of Nimes. It is
88o feet long, and tho feet high.
It is composed of three rows of
arches: The lowest tier of 6, the
second of ii, and the third of 35.
This magnificent structure was
thoroughly illustrated from half a
dozen different points of view. Here
the lecturer took occasion to correct a rather common impression,
namely, that the ancient aqueducts
were constructed throughout their
entire course upon arches. As a
matter of fact, only a relatively
small proportion of any aqueduct
was so built. The larger part was
regularly underground. This is
true even of the numerous aqueducts which brought such a bountiful supply of pure water to the city
of Rome itself. One thinks, of
course, of the great arches, some
of them even 90 feet high, which
go striding across the Campagna in
such impressive fashion; but we
know from the treatise of Froptinus, who was water commissioner
of the city about '00 A. D., that in
every case the greater part of the
aqueduct ran underground.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

(THE NEws-LETUR is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length upon
topics of interest in University circles.
Alumni especially are urged to make use
of this column. All communications, as
evidence of good faith, should be endorsed Vvith the name of the writer,
which, upon request,. will be withheld.)

October 19, 1911.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LErrER :

Dear Sir—For more than thirtyfive years our University has been
established on Maryland soil. It is
amply old enough to have associated
itself with the traditions of the
State. It has had ample time to
win its way into the affections of
the people. And yet the. paltry allowance which it expects from the
public coffers is granted more and
more grudgingly by every succeeding, Legislature. The vast, majority
of the people of Maryland—nay,
even a majority of the inhabitants
of Baltimore—seem never to have
heard of the Johns Hopkins University ; or if they have heard of it,
they think of it as an institution
which for some unknown reason or
other is always clamoring for public charity.. What is the reason for
such a condition of affairs?
.
Perhaps the • people of Maryland
do not "go in for" higher education ; perhaps many of them are
bound by ties of tradition to some
institution outside the State. But
be this as it may, in one particular
the University is itself responsible.
It has subordinated undergraduate
to graduate instruction. It has not
catered to undergraduate students.
It has, therefore, not adequately
supplied that form of instruction
which Maryland primarily needs;
and it has not made use of its opportunities to put itself in closer
touch with the people of the State.

Graduate students seldom come
into touch in after years with the
great body of the people; they seldom develop into leaders of public
opinion. They go forth from their
alma mater to occupy chairs in other
universities, and to spend their days
accumulating and dispensing knowledge. They live and die amid the
circle of the learned, unheard of
by the common run of mankind.
Such men seldom possess any opportunity of making widely known
or generally loved the name of the
institution which has sent them
forth. Nor can they aid that institution materially themselves, being
for the most part poor in the goods
of this world. Such men constitute
the larger part of the alumni of
Hopkins. From them it can expect
little assistance of any kind, either
toward meeting current expenses,
or toward "getting out to Homewood."
Of course it may be said that it
is far nobler on the part of an institution to pursue single mindedly
the advancement of learning than to
seek to butter its bread by catering
to a larger body of collegiate students ; and the argument seems
plausible enough. But to the State
it is certainly of far greater importance that its lawyers, its physicians,' its divines, and its leaders of
public opinion in general, be men
of broad intelligence and culture
than that some new chemical property or historical document be discovered. It is immeasurably better
for a State to contain within its
borders a thousand college graduates and one doctor of philosophy
than a hundred doctors of philosophy and a hundred college graduates. The State must provide for
undergraduate instruction primarily,
for graduate instruction only secondarily; and if the Johns Hopkins
deliberately chooses then to cater
primarily to graduate students, it
must expect to see its claims upon
State aid subordinated to the claims
of Washington College, St. John's
and Western Maryland.
\s a friend of the University, I
have wished to offer these objections
to what seems to me a mistaken
policy. The question of policy,
however, is of course purely within
the discretion of the University; and
no one • has a right to say that it
ought to do this or it ought to do
that. But it is within the right of
everyone to say that it ought not
to dissemble its policy; and it is
in this particular that, as a member
of the University, and an undergraduate student, I wish to find
most grievous fault with its attitude.
It is marching under false colors.
Hardly a commencement goes by at
which one member of the faculty or
another does not proclaim to the

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 23, 1911
Undergraduate Privileges.

THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to call
the attention of the library authorities to a letter in the correspondence
column concerning the partial exclusion of undergraduates from the
branch libraries on the second floor.
If the allegations contained in the
letter are true, they are serious
enough to call for immediate remedy.
Students, as we understand it, are
permitted to borrow books from the
-Historical Library, but the use of
its rooms for reading or for examination of the books on the
shelves is distinctly discouraged.
Under the system which we have at
Hopkins, the most important works
on the different subjects must be
placed in the seminary rooms, and
with the exception of the works on
English literature, the books in the
main reading-room are the cast-offs
of the various departmental libraries.
That undergraduates should not
be permitted and even encouraged
to use the books, with the same assistance from attendants as is accorded those who go into the main
reading-room, is almost inconceivable. Some of the books on the
third floor are locked in cases, and
the undergraduate who asks that
these be opened is thought to be exceding his rights. The letter which
we print today may be slightly
exaggerated, but it voices a just
Protest. Graduates and undergraduates should be permitted to share
alike in the library facilities which
the University offers.
College Women and Divorce.

Recent statistics of the use of the
divorce court by women college
graduates to settle their matrimonial
difficulties, reveal the surprising fact
that only one out of every fiftyseven unions entered into by them
ends in this way. The complete

divorce statistics. for the United
of, every
States show that one out of
twelve marriages is such a
that its final act is played in a law
court.
Comparing these two sets of figures, we come to the obvious conclusion that during their stay in
college, women have learned, in addition to their studies, some things
which fit them for married life,
and so it can be maintained that if
all women were sent to college, the
proportion of divorces to marriages
would be materially lessened. The
careful scrutinizer of these statistics, could, moreover, argue that
if he married a college girl, he
would stand 475 per cent. more
chance of finding bliss in the union.
No statistics are given for college
widows.
This method of reasoning is,
however, incomplete, for the figures
do not distinguish between types.
There is one set of people among
whom divorces are more common
than one in every twelve; there are
some sets, the poorer element, for
instance, where there is not one divorce in a hundred marriages. That
scientist who will discover what is
the average ratio for the great mass
of the population will be doing a
great service, but meantime it is
safe to say that it is not greater
than one in thirty.
The matrimonial question has two
aspects in the light of these figures.
If you marry a college girl, the
chances in favor of a divorce are
one to fifty-seven; if your choice
does not fall on a sweet girl graduate, some consideration should be
given to the question whether the
object of your affections belongs
to the larger and happier body of
the community, or to that small section of it which breeds the greatest
number of divorces. College women,
therefore. ought to stand a better
opportunity of getting married.

The cheering section at the game
with Al aryland Agricultural College
on Saturday was not as large as it
should be, and at times the efforts
at organized yells were puny. There
were some few fellows who gathered around Mr. Price, the cheerleader for this season, but many
remained in other parts of the stand
with the lady friends whom they
had escorted to see the game.
Announcement has been made
that practices for the especial benefit of the freshmen will be held this
week, and all students, new and old,
are urged to attend. The songs and
yells will be rehearsed, so that at
the game with Gettysburg, on Saturday, a better showing can be
made.
After the game on last Saturday,
Manager Getz, of the football team,
made the following statement:
"The coaehes, Captain Fulton and
myself want to appeal to all undergraduates, graduates and alumni
who attend the games, and ask
them to sit in the portion of the
stand which is reserved for the
cheering section. If the team is expected to play good football this
year, the students will have to show
that they are backing the team, for
eleven men, no matter how well.
trained they may be, cannot play
their best game unless they know
that they are getting support on the
side lines.
"The students should attend the
.games and cheer, not only when
the team is playing well and winning, but when mistakes are made.
When a man fumbles the ball, or
fails to gain, he gets disheartened
and on the next play loses some of
his vim ; but when he hears the
'Varsity yell with his name tacked
on the end, and knows that the
students are with him, he is encouraged, and plays all the harder.
At the game Saturday,the Maryland
Agricultural College rooters often
out-velled us, and undergraduates of
an institution of the prestige of
Johns Hopkins shouldn't for a moment allow this. With a team like
the one we have, and representing
a great University, we should outyell the rooters of any team which
plays at Homewood.'

In an authoritative statement concerning the rank of different American colleges in athletics, which was
recently published, Johns Hopkins
was placed fourth. Cornell was
given first 'place with five points;
Yale second, with four and a half;
Princeton third, with two and a
half, and Hopkins, Harvard, Pennsylvania, Columbia, Haverford, and
Annapolis were listed as tied for
fourth place with one point each.
One point was given to each college for each of the intercollegiate
championships held by it in one of
the sixteen sports considered. Cornell won its place by holding the
championship in rowing, crosscountry, track, hockey and fencing. To Yale is conceded first place
in golf, shooting, water polo and
swimming, gymnastics, and 'a tie in
tennis. Princeton has a tie in tennis and first place in baseball and
wrestling. Last Year Harvard had
the best team in football, Haverford in association football, Columbia in basketball, and Hopkins in
lacrosse. The fact that Hopkins
was given as high a standing as
Harvard and Columbia shows how
highly outsiders regard our athletic
ability.

Social Service Meeting.

The first of the series of meetings
held during the year by the Association will be held on Tuesday,
October 24, at 5 P. M. The suSject of the meeting will be the "Social Service Needs of Baltimore."
Talks will be given by Dr. Magruder, secretary of the Federated
Charities, and Mr. hackney, of the
Central Y. M. C. A., who has
charge of the work of teaching;
English to foreigners. The opportunities for service in the city are
numerous and varied and we hope
that many students vill attend the
meeting, although it may be impossible for them to take up any
phase of the work.

Bible Classes Organize.

The Bible Study Classes arc now
in full swing. The freshman class
studying the Life of Jesus meets in
two groups, Monday at nine o'clock,
and Friday at ten o'clock. If there
are any freshmen who intend to
enroll in these classes, but who have
not done so as yet, we wish they
would see the general secretary at
once. The sophomor class studying
the Acts and the Epistles will meet
on Friday at one o'clock. The
junior class, studying the Teachings
of the Phophets meets on Monday
at one o'clock. The senior class,
studying the Social Teachings of
Jesus, • meets on Friday at one
o'clock.
If sufficient number of men are
secured a class will be organized
for the men who have doubts and
difficulties regarding religious matters. Any students.-- desiring to
enter this class will please speak
to the general secretary about the
matter.
A cordial invitation is extended
to all students to enroll in one of
these groups.

He began writing while still in
his native State—South - Carolina.
His father, the late Benjamin Gildersleeve, of Charleston, was editor
of a religious paper, and Dr. Gildersleeve, then a young man, frequently contributed to that periodical. While at the -University of
Virginia he wrote for a newspaper
in Richmond.
"I even wrote a novel once," he
remarked reminiscently. "I was
then 23 years old. It was never
published, and the manuscript I still
have. I have written some poetry
too. In 1890 I collected my contributions to periodicals and published them in book form under
the title of 'Essays and Studies.'
Some of my verse is contained in
this."
From literature Dr. Gildersleeve
turned to _the topic of the Civil War.
The students and the faculty of the
University of Virginia were exempt
from service in the army, but the
Professor said he usually "spent
his vacations at the front." His
career as a Confederate soldier was
varied. Private, lieutenant and captain, he was in many engagements.
